node.doctext:
[N-Wing] says: (but everyone ignores:)

I want a real bug1 tracking system, not just the mostly-ignored (by me, at least :) ) [E2 bugs] e2node.
Before this thing is actually made2, we'll3 put down some ideas, so this thing is actually planned (gasp), and not just thrown together.
If you want to add something to this list, /msg [N-Wing] .

1 'bug' meaning not just 'bug', but 'suggestions' and 'ideas', as well
2 does it even need to be made? We could just use SorceForge, but I think that is more for projects, not individual sites. Or maybe there is another bug tracking software package that would be suitable.
3 'we.make_ideas' == [edev]; 'we.put_down_ideas_in_this_page' == [N-Wing], maybe [JayBonci], maybe [nate]

Let the ideas/wants begin:

  • it should most things SourceForge's bug tracker, and the Bugzilla one have ([N-Wing|N])
  • each bug should allow an [gods|admin] to change who can view the bug; maybe a bit-field (set with checkboxes in the UI part) for (so far): 'guest user' (default no), 'normal user' (default yes), 'content editors' (default yes), 'edev' (default yes), 'gods' (default yes) ([N-Wing|N])
  • allow almost anybody to create a bug (not guest user, of course) (I'm thinking this permission check could just be 1 line of code, so it would be easy to block a group, like 'normal users' if they (in general) don't report good things) ([N-Wing|N])
  • bugs should not be things like 'there are 2 [whatever] nodes'; but something like 'it is possible to have 2 e2nodes with the same title' is OK ([N-Wing|N]) [JayBonci|JB] says that's just good bug reporting

fields (this will be used as a template for the DB table) (starting info from SF)

  • request_id (probably make this correspond to the standard node_id) ([N-Wing|N])
  • summary (just the 'title') ([N-Wing|N])
  • datetime requested (creation date) ([N-Wing|N])
  • requested by (node's author) ([N-Wing|N])
  • assigned to #0 (only a user) (just #0 in case it makes sense to add more users to 1 project) (an even better way would to make this like nodegroups work - an unlimited # of things assigned to 1 group) ([N-Wing|N])
  • bug type (maybe) (bug/suggestion) ([N-Wing|N])
  • category (maybe) (HTML/security/UI/subroutine) (maybe make these come from another table)([N-Wing|N])
  • status (open/closed/working on) ([N-Wing|N])
  • priority ([N-Wing|N])
  • resolution (none (default)/accepted (if someone says they'll work on it)/fixed/invalid/won't do/works for me)
  • detail (like writeups have) ([N-Wing|N])
=========== Implementation ideas:
Type e2bug (Inherits type document):
  • Can be read by anyone
  • Can be added by anyone
  • Can be deleted by gods
  • Can be edited by owner

  • The author_user is the person who created the bug
  • The createtime is when the bug was created.
  • Doctext is used to describe the bug
  • The title would be the title of the bug (use it wisely)
  • Additional fields:
    • Priority: We can just have this a flat out number. 1, 2, 3, 4 (the order in which we'd do it, for our reference)
    • Severity: 1, 2, 3, 4 (Sev 1: Blocking, huge feature damage, Sev 2, Huge, but workaround available, Sev 3, Minor feature section, Sev 4, Small nitpicy things
    • Feature: I'd implement this choice as a nodegroup of all available features on the system. The nodegroup would contain the opcodes, htmlcodes, etc etc, themes, display pages, etc. So in the dropdown for the bug we'd have
      • message (opcode)
      • Message Inbox (superdoc)
      • etc.
    • Theme: We'd need for them to give us the theme in which the bug occurs
    • Resolution: We can either have this link out to other things, or enumerate a number: Active, Assigned, Fixed, Won't fix, Duplicate, Bad bug (like posted a bug on a non-bug area), WorksForMe / Not Repro.
    • Bug Type: Server Error, Client Error, Display Error, Wording, Engine errors, Suggestion
    • Bug_Id: An independant bug id, so that we can track bug stats a little better, and do larger bug dumps when we need to.
    • Assigned to: (open, a user, or closed) a bug should only be assigned to people in the edev group. We can seed a dropdown list with that

I want you to be able to bug something that's in the buggable group by having a Bug! link next to Edevify! etc etc. This would be helpful in making it easy to file bugs. Bugs that we report should also be acessable through the edev nodelet. "Assigned to you" in a manner similar to message inbox.

I know this is similar to what you had above, but it took a little bit of my own spin. Thoughts? -[JayBonci|jb]
